seg.seg: ... the heavenly earths were like a flight of step[s]. 2. (Seeing the salvation of the world) in following the good Law
... he was. In the path of the Law he found extreme joy. He could not bear
Auf dem Pfade des Gesetzes fand er überaus Gefallen.
On the path of the Law he exceedingly found delight.
... the (lead)er (of the citizens), the householder Kirīṭavatsa, had a daughter [lit. to K. was a daughter] (provided with) beauty like the goddess Śrī
... (being a second one) among Apsaras women, exceedingly (equipped with) loveliness of beauty
... [and] she was a girl honoured as a pearl (of women). To her also, in comparison with all [other] women
... as often as she would come to a place [where she can be] seen, so often [did] the one [admiring] her beauty ...
... wie oft sie in das Blickfeld [jemandes] gekommen war, so oft machte der, (von) ihrer Gestalt (gefesselt(?)), ... (weder) ein Augenblinzeln, noch auch machte er eine Bewegung des Körpers.
... as often as she had come into [someone's] field of vision, as often he would make/do, (enthralled(?) by) her shape ..., (neither) the winking of an eye nor either a bodily movement.
... he did not blink [lit. make even the wink of an eye], nor did he make a movement with his body. 1. For exactly this re(ason)
(Aus) eben dem Gru(nde) ... legten ihr (die Angehörigen) den Namen (Unmādayantī) bei.
(For) exactly this rea(son) ... ([her] relatives) gave her the name (Unmādayantī).
([her] relatives) gave her the name (Unmādayantī). Thereupon her father let hear the king of this matter.
... Presently [upon] the lord [is] (the judgment) about either taking [her as wife] for himself or giving [her] up to others
... (Thereupon the king) commanded the Brahmins of (all lands), who were knowledgeable about the marks of woman, [saying]: Come here, ye skilled ones!
... (if she is suitable for me or if) she [is] not suitable. Thereupon the girl’s father, this householder, (having invited) the Brahmins
... (let the Brahmins into his house, he said to Unmādayantī: My dear,) distribute (by yourself) to the Brahmins portions to eat!" Having said “So it will be”, then Unmādayantī (went away) ...
«Give the brahmins a piece of the food!» Having said, «so it will be!», Unmādayantī …

p.note: This manuscript has consistent spelling of double virāma (i.e. with stroke and dot) with the notable exception of waṣt in the phrase waṣt lmo, which is in both occasions spelled without virāma dot.
The translation is largely based on 42-43, and .
The Tocharian version is remarkably close to the Sanskrit text in Āryaśūra's Jātakamālā (cf. 80ff.).
The tune here has 4x12 syllables, rhythm 4/4/4. (–)klisṣiṃ sark corresponds to Skt. sopānamālā 'winding stairs'. Cf. 80, line 22 and 81, verse 3.
Cf. 81, line 4. Note that the dot corresponds to the end of a pāda in the Sanskrit original even though the Tocharian text is in prose.
Cf. 81, line 5. There is no direct parallel in the Sanskrit original; the meter has 4x14 syllables, rhythm 7/7.
Cf. 81, line 13-14. Note that the Sanskrit original has the more general term pariveṣayati 'offer/serve food'.
